results.title: Creating a homely atmosphere
results.creator_credit: Dept of Health, Richmond Implementation Unit, Tony Shaddock, Helen Edwards and Tim Abbott
results.brief_description: Designed to introduce the intellectual disability residential care worker to some simple ways of creating a homelike environment in the physical sense with furnishing and decor, how to create a desirable psychological atmosphere through community involvement and high quality staff-resident, staff-staff and resident-resident interactions, an interpretation of the term “normalisation” and how this principle might be applied in a residential setting and the recognition of the individual resident’s rights in what is their home. Accompanied by 32p. in-service training manual.

results.title: Creating a dance (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The first part of the film traces stages in the creation of a demonstration of dance movement, examining the constituent parts and illustrating how the solutions to some of the associated problems were evolved. The second part presents the entire demonstration without comment. Dance direction and narration by Valerie Preston-Dunlop.

results.title: Creating
results.creator_credit: Peter Montagnon, Alasdair Clayre, Patrick Lui and Nigel Houghton
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program looks at the world of contemporary Chinese art, exploring the philosophic and historic influences that shape it. The way that Chinese artists pursue the essence of “reality” is examined as are the techniques which combine traditional values with unconventional materials to produce works that are resplendently Chinese.

results.title: Created equal
results.creator_credit: Michael Latham, Video Arts and Graham Massey
results.brief_description: Milton Friedman discusses freedom and equality, arguing that a society which maximises the scope for individual choice and action will be more successful at creating equal opportunities for all than a society which seeks to achieve quality through distribution of wealth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Latham, Video Arts and Graham Massey

results.title: Crayon
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the wide techniques which may be used in working with crayons - notching, scratching, rubbing, grating and melting. Drawing can be on paper, wood, metal, glass and fabric. Shows artists creating brilliantly coloured and textures work.

results.title: Crayfish for Julie
results.brief_description: Depicts a day in the life of a fisherman catching crayfish off the coast near Fremantle, Western Australia. Briefly traces the growth and development of the crayfish industry. Made with the co operation of the Department of Fisheries Western Australia. Narrated by Clive Winmill.

results.title: Crayfish coast
results.creator_credit: Derek Wright, New Zealand National Film Unit and Conon Fraser
results.brief_description: The isolated crayfishing settlement of Ngawi is at the eastern end of Cook Strait. This film looks at the livelihood of the crayfishermen and their families in the small stark settlement.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Derek Wright, New Zealand National Film Unit and Conon Fraser

results.title: Cray season
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Tasmanian State Film Unit and Rodney Musch
results.brief_description: The crayfish, seen not as a table delicacy, but as a living creature whose survival is threatened. Briefly looks at its life history, its vulnerability, its predators, and man its greatest enemy. Feild researchers take the camera underwater to the world of ‘Janus Lalander’, the southern crayfish.

results.title: Crash zone
results.creator_credit: Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: The Crash Zone is the place where the five friends, Mike, Pi, Marcello, Bec and Ram go to test drive the games. Combining technological fact and fantasy with issues such as friendship, teamwork and loyalty, the series follows the exciting online and real-life adventures of the friends.

constellations_other.name: Television and creative constraint
constellations_other.description: Making art for the screen is dependent on time, resources, and infrastructure. Where technology could have posed a barrier, these television producers saw an opportunity, instead.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Disney Channel Australia and Australian Children’s Television Foundation
results.description: Television series aimed at pre and young teens about a group of kids who land the after-school job of their dreams, testing computer games. The Crash Zone is the place where the five friends, Mike, Pi, Marcello, Bec and Ram go to test drive the games created by Alexandra Davis, owner of the software company Catalyst, before they go on the market. Combining technological fact and fantasy with issues such as friendship, teamwork and loyalty, the series follows the exciting online and real-life adventures of the friends, who range in age from 11-16. Although aimed at 9 to 13 year olds, “Crash Zone” is thought provoking and appealing to all age levels and can be used to encourage discussion about cultural, social, philosophic and technological issues related to ‘new media’, information systems and the rights of individuals in a ‘networked world’. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv
description_for_label: Television series aimed at pre and young teens about a group of kids who land the after-school job of their dreams, testing computer games. The Crash Zone is the place where the five friends, Mike, Pi, Marcello, Bec and Ram go to test drive the games created by Alexandra Davis, owner of the software company Catalyst, before they go on the market. Combining technological fact and fantasy with issues such as friendship, teamwork and loyalty, the series follows the exciting online and real-life adventures of the friends, who range in age from 11-16. Although aimed at 9 to 13 year olds, “Crash Zone” is thought provoking and appealing to all age levels and can be used to encourage discussion about cultural, social, philosophic and technological issues related to ‘new media’, information systems and the rights of individuals in a ‘networked world’. Teaching resources can be found at: http://www.actf.com.au/learning_centre_new/Learning_frameset.htm Accompanying website at: www.crashzone.tv
